content:
Here are some yoga poses that target your core and legs that you can try at home:

**Core Strengthening Poses:**

1. **Boat Pose (Paripurna Navasana)**: Sit with your legs crossed, engage your core, and balance on your seat bones. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
2. **Plank Pose (Phalakasana)**: Start in a high push-up position, with your hands shoulder-width apart. Engage your core, keep your body straight, and hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
3. **Side Plank Pose (Vasisthasana)**: Lie on your side with your feet stacked, lift your hips off the ground, and balance on your forearm and the side of your foot. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute on each side.

**Leg Strengthening Poses:**

1. **Warrior II Pose (Virabhadrasana II)**: Stand with your feet wide apart, with one foot facing forward and the other foot at a 90-degree angle. Bend your front knee and stretch your arms out to the sides. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute on each side.
2. **Tree Pose (Vrksasana)**: Stand on one leg, with the other foot resting on the inner thigh. Engage your core, lift your arms up, and gaze forward. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute on each leg.
3. **Eagle Pose (Garudasana)**: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then bend your knees slightly and cross one leg over the other. Wrap your arms around your legs and hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute on each side.

**Poses that Target Both Core and Legs:**

1. **Chair Pose (Utkatasana)**: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then bend your knees and lower your body down into a squat. Keep your back straight, engage your core, and hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
2. **Lizard Pose (Utthan Pristhasana)**: Start on all fours, then step one foot forward and place your hands on the ground beside your front foot. Lower your back knee down towards the ground, keeping your front thigh parallel to the ground. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute on each side.

Remember to:

* Listen to your body and modify or come out of the pose if you experience any discomfort or pain.
* Breathe deeply and focus on your breath to help you engage your core and maintain proper alignment.
* Start slow and gradually increase your hold time as you build strength and endurance.

Happy practicing!
